title: -Fission Cross Section Measurement Of U-235 And  Pu-239 For Low Energy Neutrons.-

freetext: 2200 m/sec value obtained
from a fit to the sigma(F)/sigma(B(N,a)) data
of the world recommended shape.
2200 m/sec value obtained
by fitting to the sigma(F)/sigma(B(N,a)) data
the world recommended shape.
2200 m/sec value.
2200 m/sec, mean value
from two determinations, viz. 1.With U-235
as monitor, and 2.With B-10 as monitor.
.Presence in the neutron beam of neutrons with
harmonic wave-lengths (ff-counting and B-counting)
.Background noise (B-counting)
.Dead time (FF counting, B- counting, fission foil
Alpha counting).
.Geometrical efficiency (FF counting, B- counting,
fission foil alpha-counting)
.Discrimination and selfabsorption (alpha spectra)
.Backscattering (ff-counting, B-counting, fission
foil alpha counting)
.Isotopic composition (fission foils)
.Alpha pile up (Pu- measurements)
.Different neutron flux upon target and monitor.
.Neutron beam profile.
A solid state detector in low geometry
(0.01 of 2*pi) for counting the fission fragments
the energy resolution was about 2 percent, 1 cm**2
sensitive area, resistivity 450 Ohm*cm, 30 volt
bias.
At the energy of 0.275 eV, the
fission fragments are counted with two xenon
filled scintillators detecting the two coincident
fragments in a 4*pi geometry. Pressure 1.5 atm.,
Energy resolution about 20 percent. The xenon gas
was purified by circulation over a calcium purifier
heated at 400 deg C.
The total error given includes all the errors,
except those due to the uncertainties in the
isotopic composition and chemical purity of the
boron foils.
Crystal spectrometer ( Three orien-
tations used),
El-3 reactor in saclay, 18 mw power.
Reactor neutrons.
Comparison of fission foils with natural boron
foils at 3 energies. The 2200 m/sec value is
obtained by fitting the cross section shape to
these 3 data points.
.Boron foils deposited by electron bombardment under
vacuum on aluminium backings weighted before their
removal from the vacuum system. Elemental boron was
used, containing 19.81 at. Percent of B-10. However
the preparation of the foil may enrich the foil in
B-10 to about 20.3 at.Perc. This effect has not been
checked and is one of the main sources of error of
the experiment. Two layers are used - 3.329e+18
atoms/cm**2, and 4.183e+18 atoms/cm**2.
.Fissile foil preparation fully described in nucl.
Instr. Meth 21(1963)161. Plastic foils of about 25
micrograms/cm**2 are metallized with an evaporated
aluminium layer to reduce strongly the light
transmission. Fissile layers deposited by electro-
spraying of an acetate uranium or plutonium solution.
In U-layer, composed of a mixture of U-O2(CH3COO)2 and
U-O2(CH3COO)3, 2/3 of the total weight was fissile
material. More details in Table 1 of reference.
